Specific Details: We welcomed the Criminal Law (sexual Offences) Bill 2014 but felt it fell short in having no statutory definition of consent. Given the difficulties in proving an absence of consent in sexual offence cases, we believe a definition would go some way towards clarifying the uncertainties in this area.
Subject Matter: We welcomed the Criminal Law (sexual Offences) Bill 2014 but felt it fell short in having no statutory definition of consent. Given the difficulties in proving an absence of consent in sexual offence cases, we believe a definition would go some way towards clarifying the uncertainties in this area.
Intended Results: The inclusion of a statutory definition on consent in the Crimal Law (Sexual Offences) Bill
Lobbying Activities: The one area that we believe would strengthen the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Bill 2014 and keep more victims of sexual crimes in the Criminal Justice System is a definition of consent and it is not included. The DRCC, having consulted with our sister RCC’s, the Union of Students of Ireland and the White Ribbon Campaign, launched a national campaign on AskConsent supported by Cosc. It was a Bill Board and a social media campaign. The main purpose was educational and encouraging young people to talk about what consent means. In educating young people how to communicate appropriately during sexual encounters, it will also play a preventative role by reducing the potential for non-consensual sexual activity to occur.|Meeting|2-5

Specific Details: Sexual Abuse and Violence in Ireland, was published in 2002. It was the most comprehensive research on attitudes and beliefs to sexual violence in Ireland. Since its publication, it has helped to inform policies across government departments on sexual violence. The DRCC have and will continue to lobby for a second SAVI because we believe it is imperative that the policies and services needed in the area of sexual violence are appropriately informed by up to date empirical longitudinal research.
Subject Matter: Sexual Abuse and Violence in Ireland, was published in 2002. It was the most comprehensive research on attitudes and beliefs to sexual violence in Ireland. Since its publication, it has helped to inform policies across government departments on sexual violence. The DRCC have and will continue to lobby for a second SAVI because we believe it is imperative that the policies and services needed in the area of sexual violence are appropriately informed by up to date empirical longitudinal research.
Intended Results: Secure funding for the publication of a second SAVI.
Lobbying Activities:
SAVI was the most comprehensive piece of research on attitudes and beliefs about sexual violence in Ireland and its findings confirmed and validated the stories that were being told to helplines over the previous 25 years of the RCC movement in Ireland, in therapy rooms, doctors’ surgeries and A & Es around the country, of the prevalence of sexual violence in Ireland. In lobbying TD’s we highlight the need to conduct a second SAVI so that we can have comparative rigorous research and an answer to the question - does the increase in the number of victims using the services mean 
1)	There is an increase in the prevalence of these crimes? OR
2)	Is it that the victims are coming forward now and reporting the crime to the RCCs and to the Gardai?|Meeting|2-5

Specific Details: Open Prison provision in Ireland and the proposed closure of the Training Unit
DPOs Lobbied: Fergal Black|Director of Services or Equivalent|Irish Prison Service::Michael Donnellan|Director General|Department of Justice and Equality::Frances Fitzgerald|Tánaiste and Minister|Department of Justice and Equality::Ivana Bacik|Senator|Seanad
Subject Matter: Open Prison provision in Ireland and the proposed closure of the Training Unit
Intended Results: Clarify impact on prisoners affected with goal of reversing the decision and/or ensuring access to equivalent regimes in other prisons::Demonstrate that the decision runs contrary to previous policy commitments
Lobbying Activities:
Letters sent to Director General of Irish Prison Service (13 March, 13 April); Mountjoy Campus Governor (13 March, 31 March); Director of Care and Rehabilitation (4 April); An Tánaiste (18 April); and DJE Strategic Review of Penal Policy  Implementation Oversight Group (18 April) outlining:
- IPRT's serious concerns at proposed closure of the Training Unit
- the negative impacts on prisoners currently detained
- requesting information on how regimes will be maintained for prisoners transferred to closed prisons
- identifying policy contradiction of reducing open prison provision in Ireland
- requesting investment in the Training Unit so that it can remain open until alternative semi-open facilities are made available in the Dublin region
- requesting additional measures and investment in Mountjoy West to better facilitate 'normalisation' regimes
- and requesting more information on future plans|Letter|6-10::Meeting with Mountjoy Campus management and Director of Care & Rehabilitation (29 March 2017) to outline IPRT's serious concerns, seek more information, and request specific measures for prisoners affected towards maintaining equivalent semi-open regime and ensuring prisoner safety on transfer to other prisons.|Meeting|1::Information to Senator Ivana Bacik (29 March) detailing IPRT's key concerns in relation to the closure of the Training Unit, and emphasising the negative impacts on prisoner rehabilitation.|Email|1
